p: Among the PHAs, poly(3-hydroxybutyrate) (PHB) is the most simple and common representative of PHAs. This is the reason why it is the most widely investigated for the development of PHA-based antimicrobial systems. From a processing point of view, the main drawback of PHB is its very low resistance to thermal degradation, since PHB has a melting temperature (around 170–180 °C) that is close to the degradation temperature (270 °C) [ 240]. Thus, although PHAs are still processed by melt compounding [ 264, 265, 266, 267], the most recent studies on antimicrobial PHA systems are focused on the preparation of active PHA-based materials at room temperature [ 268, 269, 270, 271].
